title: Intolerance Strikes Again: Australian Couple harassed over tattoo of Indian Goddess, forced to make written apology in Bengaluru (Watch Video)
text:
Intolerance Strikes Again: Australian Couple harassed over tattoo of Indian Goddess, forced to make written apology in Bengaluru (Watch Video) By Sakshita Khosla on October 21, 2015 at 3:40 AM Comments Bengaluru, October 21: In a shameful incident, an Australian couple was allegedly harassed and made to apologize over a tattoo depicting a Hindu Goddess, by an indignant mob at a restaurant situated in an upmarket area of the city. Matthew Gordon, 21 and his girlfriend Emily Kassianou, 20, were harassed and were even taken to police station, where they were forced to make a written apology for ‘intentionally spreading hate’, claimed a report by the Indian Express. According to the report, Matt and Emily, were visiting the famous Konark restaurant in the city, when a group of people, noticed the tattoo depicting Goddess Yellamma on Matt’s shin. Some people started clicking pictures of the tattoo, which they claimed was offensive and hurtful to Hindu sentiments. The couple objected to the pictures, but soon the group created a commotion, with some people demanding that Matt take tattoo off or else cover his shin up. Some people even suggested that Matt remove the part of his skin, where the tattoo was inked! Also Read: Pranab Mukherjee raises concern over growing intolerance in the nation The police were called and even they suggested that Matt cover the tattoo up. One of the people involved in the commotion was a local small time BJP worker, Ramesh Kumar. An Indian friend of the couple intervened and agreed for the couple to be taken to the local police station, to resolve the dispute. The Ashok Nagar police then instructed Gordon to make a written apology and wear pants and learn Kannada. The video footage posted by The Hindu shows an exasperated Gordon asking the police, what they expected him to do about his tattoo. 
EXCLUSIVE: Australian harassed in Bengaluru by BJP workers over sporting a tattoo of a Hindu goddess on his leg – thne.ws/1OCTdaN 
Posted by Hindu Hindu on Sunday, October 18, 2015 The apology read,”My name is Matthew, visiting from Melbourne, Australia. I am very sorry for offending Hindu religious beliefs by my tattoo. I did not know of this auspicious custom in regard to tattoo placement. I will make sure to cover it up while I am in India. Thank you for educating me in what is appropriate in regard to body art on my body. I am also extremely sorry for using inappropriate language.” Traumatised by the whole experience, Gordon quite expectedly said that he did not want to stay in Bangalore any more. Also Read: Marathi writer Pradnya Pawar returns awards to protest intolerance The events of the past few weeks have been distressing for the liberal secular and tolerant Indian, who believes in and stands for pluralism. The effects of Hindutva extremism have become too pertinent to ignore right from the outright alarming Dadri lynching incident, to the relatively less violent ink attacks on Sudheendra Kulkarni and Jammu and Kashmir MLA Rashid engineer. There is no question that acts of intolerance are on the rise in India and this particular incident goes a long way in proving just how rampant they are becoming.
